issue.title: "runtime thread cancelled: TimedOut"

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
I get a "runtime thread cancelled: TimedOut" on a ~~very busy machine~~ (edit: the machine is 50% idle) that is using reqwest from 16 threads. This is a new problem after I upgraded reqwest.

I appear to be able to cause the issue by `strace -fffp <pid> 2>&1 | less` and exiting the command 2 or 3 times.

relevant change: https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/commit/a82232f0eef7d7b2766fa0cbb69f49f64594e6b6 (but not bisected).

issue.title: HTTP retries

repository.name: tough
repository.description: Rust libraries and tools for using and generating TUF repositories

issue.body: On connection resets, the `Read`er should retry the HTTP connection for the rest of the range (similar to wgetâ€™s default behavior).

issue.title: Possible feature request: connection attempts

labels.name: B-rfc
labels.description: Blocked: Request for comments. More discussion would help move this along.

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
Hi.

Consider the following example:

```rust
...
    reqwest::Client::new()
        .connection_attempts(Some(5)) // notice this line
        .post("http://www.baidu.com")
        .form(&[("one", "1")])
        .send()?;
...
```

Suppose this client is working in a radio controlled flying device using an unstable mobile network to send photos of agricultural pests automatically, the feature would allow the client to try to resend the request until it couldn't connect to the server.

In general, the programmers implements such feature on their applications, but it could be a useful `reqwest` feature. :-)

issue.title: chore: add retries with backoff to schema download
issue.body: generally nice to have, might fix the spurious errors we're seeing in CI

issue.title: How do I get more details about an error?

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

body:
it seems that folks from AWS based their `aws-sdk-dynamodb` ([doc](https://docs.rs/aws-sdk-dynamodb/latest/aws_sdk_dynamodb/client/struct.Builder.html#method.retry_policy)) retry strategy on `tower::retry::Policy` ([doc](https://docs.rs/tower/0.4.13/tower/retry/trait.Policy.html)) 

and from my user point of view, they did a great job to hide the internal complexity behind their API, using their own `aws_smithy_client::retry::Config` ([doc](https://docs.rs/aws-smithy-client/0.54.1/aws_smithy_client/retry/struct.Config.html)) ðŸ‘

And there also exists [`retry stratagy`](https://docs.rs/ethers/1.0.2/ethers/providers/trait.RetryPolicy.html) in `ethers-rs`.
Maybe reqwest can put it on the agenda.
Or I am glad to submit a pr.
â„¹ï¸ I also opened a feature request for retrying any `Future<Output=Result<...>>` (including reqwest ones) with `tokio`: https://github.com/tokio-rs/tokio/issues/5596

issue.title: chore(l1): Migrate to Alloy

labels.name: K-chore
labels.description: Kind: general fixes not relating to a bug

labels.name: M-port
labels.description: Meta: Ports code to new implementations

repository.name: magi
repository.description: A blazing fast OP Stack rollup client written in Rust

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
**Description**

Migrates the `l1` module to Alloy.

Two main concerns with this pr as it stands. Currently removed retrying from the l1 chain watcher provider since the `RetryClient` previously used is from `ethers` and I'm not seeing a good alternative. It also seems that the `reqwest::ClientBuilder` [does not offer a retry policy](https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/issues/316).

The second concern is that the rpc `Log` type returned from the alloy provider does not hydrate the block information needed to construct the user deposit information. As in, it is missing the `l1 block number`, `l1 block hash`, and `log index` (within the block). As a work around, I've modified the log fetching to query each block's log set at a time so we can hydrate this information ourselves (assuming logs are returned in their canonical block ordering from the provider). It would be much more efficient for the provider to hydrate this data such that we can batch rpc requests. Especially since we currently set the range to be 1000 blocks starting at the provided block number.

**Metadata**

Fixes #233
